para.sentence: The \mathit{9j} symbol may be defined either in terms of \mathit{3j} symbols or equivalently in terms of \mathit{6j} symbols: \begin{Bmatrix}j_{11}&j_{12}&j_{13}\\ j_{21}&j_{22}&j_{23}\\ j_{31}&j_{32}&j_{33}\end{Bmatrix}=\sum_{\mbox{\scriptsize all }m_{rs}}\begin{ pmatrix}j_{11}&j_{12}&j_{13}\\ m_{11}&m_{12}&m_{13}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}j_{21}&j_{22}&j_{23}\\ m_{21}&m_{22}&m_{23}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}j_{31}&j_{32}&j_{33}\\ m_{31}&m_{32}&m_{33}\end{pmatrix}\*\begin{pmatrix}j_{11}&j_{21}&j_{31}\\ m_{11}&m_{21}&m_{31}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}j_{12}&j_{22}&j_{32}\\ m_{12}&m_{22}&m_{32}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}j_{13}&j_{23}&j_{33}\\ m_{13}&m_{23}&m_{33}\end{pmatrix}, , \begin{Bmatrix}j_{11}&j_{12}&j_{13}\\ j_{21}&j_{22}&j_{23}\\ j_{31}&j_{32}&j_{33}\end{Bmatrix}=\sum_{j}(-1)^{2j}(2j+1)\begin{Bmatrix}j_{11} &j_{21}&j_{31}\\ j_{32}&j_{33}&j\end{Bmatrix}\begin{Bmatrix}j_{12}&j_{22}&j_{32}\\ j_{21}&j&j_{23}\end{Bmatrix}\begin{Bmatrix}j_{13}&j_{23}&j_{33}\\ j&j_{11}&j_{12}\end{Bmatrix}.
The \mathit{9j} symbol may also be written as a finite triple sum equivalent to a terminating generalized hypergeometric series of three variables with unit arguments.
See Srinivasa Rao and Rajeswari (1993, pp. 7 and 125â€“132) andRosengren (1999).
